Remember, as the human race we should care about more than just one division of people, but at the same time we get too quickly distracted by the greater suffering of one group and forget almost entirely about the rest. Completely aside from that, Riot choice of charity was at least well researched and i have all confidence that the money will be used correctly.

I can't seem to reply to you for some reason, Honeybadger2198. But hopefully this will suffice.

I never said the "quote" you used. I used the word ignorant. Ignorance is a thing literally everyone alive is guilty of. No one knows everything. There's no shame in admitting ignorance. There is shame in not admitting it (something I, like everyone else, am also guilty of).

I didn't say they, or you, are stupid. Maybe it was late and you were busy and that's why you misquoted me. Many balls in the air and whatnot. But if you want to try to rebut me again, please do it properly.

I wanted to address you directly, Mr. Autocratic Facial Hair.

Guess what? Words hurt. As Deathcap Veigar illustrated, they come with powerful associations and connotations for many people. I don't care about the opinions of random strangers as such, but when someone calls someone - not just me - a faggot, it illustrates that the world is still hostile to me. That's not the best thing to be reminded of.

And I'm lucky. I never experienced too much harassment for my sexual preferences. Many have experienced people screaming that word at them while hurling things, or worse. That does give the word power. It's not a matter of "letting" something get to you. It's a matter of your brain associating it with a negative experience, in a manner you have no control over.

Try having some empathy.

And even if you do dismiss the seriousness of the issue, shouldn't the guy still be banned? He's still creating a negative environment for people, no matter how trivial you may find it. I wouldn't want to log in to a game, something I do for fun, to be harassed.
Does blocking someone not prevent them from communicating with you? It would be a pretty unfortunate oversight if blocking them didn't work :(

How about this? Let's take the time to thank Rito for donating the money to a cause that ** IS** relevant to LoL. As someone who attained a series of bans and reports due to negative attitude and toxicity (mostly relating to killing oneself), it took a while to get out of that hole. For ranked queues, instead of going in with a negative attitude, I talk to my entire team in champ select just to break the ice so that we can communicate better within the games I play. Through this, I don't care if a player is disabled or is another ethnicity. It all comes down to learning to communicate together instead of splitting your team apart.

Good job Rito for this choice and I hope to see what the future donation endeavors will be like!
Thank you based Nick Allen. Much love for this decision. Looking forward to more smart decisions made by you guys. Thank you for continuing to do your best to cultivate an amazing community.

Now before you start name calling me into Oblivion... out of all the Charities out there..... this one......


Granted the $$$ amount is rather small so high expectations are limited however I fail to understand the cost/benefit of 30,000$ to a charity that expeditures are mostly human resources (paying staff to engage) vs capital expenditures.  A donation to this charity in other words only lasts the duration of the $$$ whereas a capital expenditure (like building someone a house or scholarship) will last for years to come.

If someone wants me to explain this logic further I be happy to do so with more factual argumentation.

That is an excellent point.

I think most people have a favorite charity. Personally, mine is Charity: Water [sic]. I feel like once everyone has THE most basic human need, then we can focus more on other things, like sick children getting iPads. Which is how i feel, but is also an oversimplification.

Still, I like this charity a lot. But you raise a good point. If they built community centers (I wish I had such a thing in my area) that'd be cool, and more lasting.

But the problem is, one group can only do so much. And they're all valuable. They all do good. It's hard to say one charity is less deserving of funds than another (barring malfeasance and misuse of funds) once you see the effects. One life saved because this money went to hiring another person to be able to heelp someone (and also make rent) someone is great.

Getting into pure mathematics of the benefits; of how many people helped/saved is a very convoluted philosophical debate, and a hard argument to make due to the nuances of how funding has to bee used.
I would love to see them send out scholarships.

Whatever building they build will likely require human resources expenditures to staff it. The problem of depression isn't like the problem of homelessness or other problems related to lack of resources, so it's not like you can build a house for one person and just give it to them.

It would cost a lot of money to set up a scholarship(one that won't just run out in a few years), and it would only benefit the recipient. Also, competing for said scholarship is probably difficult for depressed LGBTQ youth, and having a panel choose a recipient would be fairly difficult. Consider that you could change someone's life by giving them $2000, or they could have a good talk about their feelings and how to deal with their situation that would help them much more.

I think that, if we're talking about capital expenditures, what would be more effective would be setting up more programs like Trevorspace. Essentially, rather than investing large amounts of capital into a relatively small number of people, invest a large lump sum into something that benefits the community. However, supporting said investment requires human resources expenditures, for development and support.

So, the fact that they're spending on human resources doesn't mean they're a bad charity. They've already made capital expenditures(setting up a help line, Trevorspace, etc.), and now support those through human resources in addition to those related to running the charity.

Hi GrandAlliance,

I'm no expert in this, but let me explain to you what a service based charity is for.

In the grand scheme of things, big city center and metropolis, have LGBT Community center or even YMCA to foster some good community and support the people in needs.

However, when you talk about suicide/crisis hotline; you can't have community center everywhere. When you are talking about "capital expenditure" and profitability, having a community center in a remote town to support 1 person, not so great heh?

A charity like this, a service-based charity, in its current form, enable in the cheapest way possible, to reach every single person in need across the United States, because having access to a phone is usually easy. It also enables the person to do it anonymously without having to go through that LGBT center door if he doesn't want to be seen by his peer.

Your logic is fine, that any charity should look into not fishing for someone, but teaching them how to fish, so it's sustainable; but when we are talking about service based life-crisis topics; you just need that one person who can answer the phone and prevent the worst to happen. Sadly, your capital expenditure, in this case, doesn't do much.

However, they do get involve into human expenditure, they don't only support the youth in crisis, they also work with other organization and school to make sure that the alleviate the root cause, not just threat the symptoms.

Hope this helps you understand this with a different point of view; again, not an expert, it's only my 2 cents.

Riot, this means a tremendous deal to me, probably more than you know.  Several years back I was among the LGBTQ youth who had been kicked out of home, and I seriously considered suicide twice.  Thankfully, I made it through this low point of my life relatively unscathed, as proven by these words I write today.  But the horrible reality is... not everyone makes it.  Here's hoping that we can help build a future where that is no longer the case.

I love you guys, the work you do, as well as your dedication to honesty and openly discussing these issues within our community.  Thank you so much for everything.

I personally like those statistics that actual bullying gets more reports than swearing.

I also approve of the consideration put into the charity selection and the final choice.  One earlier comment didn't appreciate the fact that LGBTQ youth face far more bullying and rejection from peers and family than "normal" teens.

Heck, I'm not square with my family's religion and THEY have bullied and rejected me on that alone and it's pushing me towards the brink of insanity myself.  And I only have to live with them four months out of the year nowadays.  If I had to live with them full-time now like I (obviously) did as a teenager with my new ideology, I would be in a really bad spot.  Yet, I _still_ would be better off than some LGBTQ teens out there.  

So yeah.  No one deserves to be bullied, whether you're LGBTQ or straight/cis/whatever, or whether you agree or disagree with your parents on morality issues (like how to treat LGBTQ folk), or whether you're a feeding silver 5 scrub in League (me) or best-mid-world (Faker, probably).  No one, end of story.

Just so happens that LGBTQ kids don't have a lot of support, and this charity is working to address that.  Kudos to the Trevor Project for their work, and kudos to Riot for supporting them.

I think it's awesome that Riot is donating the fine money to charity, and I have no problem with supporting the LGBTQ community with help like crisis and suicide prevention, but it seems a little bit weird to me that so much focus is put on that community. With less than 3% of the US identifying under that category, I feel like the money would be better used if given to an organization that helped EVERYONE, not just that 3%. It's not like they're the only ones who have depression problems or anything along those lines, and as a straight guy I feel like a lot of the time LGBTQ people get a lot more attention than everyone else to make up for not getting attention or support in the past, and that isn't really equality.

LGBTQ youth have the highest rate of suicide of all youth in America, because even now in 2015 there are a lot of people out there who look down and abuse because we're different. There's a lot of attention right now not only because of that, but there's a large push for equality and rights- which kind of pushes the whole community into the spotlight.
As a gay man who suffered through exactly what this charity fights against, thank you, Riot. Just because something doesn't happen to you personally, doesn't mean it's not a problem...
